If I could give this game a neutral review, I could. It's a fun game at it's base, you do exactly what you bought the game in order to do. There are a few glaring issues and massive inconveniences/immersion breakers which honestly need to be addressed. 

First and foremost the graphical issues, I have a relatively high end rig and there's no reason why my PC should be running hot, it's clear the developers have failed to properly optimise the game, there's a lot of stuttering, ghosting etc.

Next is the gameplay itself. I'll be speaking from a Single player only perspective. Whilst it is fun and I'd say it is indeed a construction sim, there's a lot of things that just seem unnecessarily tedious. Starting with the lack of any AI helper. Just simple tasks such as milling or concreting you're forced to either do yourself, or just 'skip' the job entirely. Why has nobody thought that perhaps it would be more fun to have stages of the job be AI managed whilst you do supply runs, machine transport etc, just an idea. And on the topic of machine transport, if you do a job that required 4-6 machines, whilst you can transport some together using a truck and a trailer, some you can't and sometimes you just can't be bothered, and if you cant be bothered then you literally have to jump in each machine and fast travel to the job site individually. That includes transitioning from the game, to a loading screen, 8-12 times. Extremely annoying, why isn't there an option to just move all machines to the site at once? The jobs can become repetitive, and at that point you just want certain elements to be done by an AI rather than just skipped outright.

There's also the controls which are unnecessarily overcomplicated, mainly looking at the track machines. Why not have an option to go from using Q,E/Z,C to WASD?

The progression system and the economy I have no gripes. But on the topic of machines, whilst you can get certain machines in larger sizes, some you can't like the compactors for example, why are there no Heavy Rollers in the game? The DLCs don't address this either.

TLDR, it's a fine game, but there's a lot of quality of life mechanics missing which just make aspects of the game extremely tedious. There also is no automation, you just have the option to skip parts of a job. If you're happy to want to do everything including the menial tasks by yourself (Unless you're playing with others) then this game is for you, if not then you'll quickly find yourself burnt out to a point you just can't be bothered anymore.

By far the best construction sim on the market at the moment. It has licensed brands, a good economy, and fairly solid digging physics‚Äîonly really rivalled by Out of Ore. The blend of machinery works well. However, it lacks the manual-labour side that it could really benefit from.

They previously teased a demolition-focused DLC or future update, along with more attachments that would be interchangeable for excavators. Unfortunately, only a couple of machines actually got bucket-swap functionality, and both are lacklustre. In my opinion, neither of them hold their worth, so you‚Äôll rarely use them.

The game also lacks consequences. There‚Äôs no real tipping over or getting properly stuck, which would add much-needed challenge. Roadcraft handles both of these elements well while keeping the Construction Simulator 2015 approach to loading physics for cargo and machinery. Meanwhile, this game has a very rigid and restrictive loading system which‚Äîwhile sometimes more realistic‚Äîends up feeling tedious. I‚Äôve seen some dodgy loads in real life that this game would never allow.

Some machines are also missing features you‚Äôd expect: excavators with blades that don‚Äôt move, dozer blades that can‚Äôt tilt properly, buckets that can‚Äôt heap material, and the inability to stockpile excess material to remove at the end of a job. Instead, it‚Äôs ‚Äúload it now or lose it.‚Äù DLC with friends also locks out some options. Certain machines can hold more material, cover more width, or just do the job better, but there‚Äôs no clear way to tell this without trial and error.

The last thing I‚Äôll mention is probably why the latter half of this review sounds less positive. The game‚Äôs roadmap made it seem like it would receive longer-term support. As someone who‚Äôs been here since announcement, it was disappointing when support was suddenly cut‚Äîespecially considering how much potential the game still had. Adding Steam Workshop support for machines, missions, and maps alone would have given the game massive longevity (technically that‚Äôs three features, but who‚Äôs counting).

Also, seeing them drop the pocket editions onto PC feels like a desperate move, which hurts to say because I really do like this game a lot.

It's a really fun simulator as long as you aren't expecting it to be like a Microsoft Construction Simulator. It's got a ton of issues, but is still enjoyable. With all the issues I have with the game, a recommended review sounds odd. I often prefer negative reviews over positive ones as they tend to give you a better idea of what you can expect than short "this game is great" anyone who likes a game would put up.

Some of the biggest issues would be the optimization isn't great and struggles to run smoothly with graphics turned up to see all the detail the game has to offer. This heavily impacts first person views where adding reflections to the mirrors risks heavy frame drops. First person machine operation has a few other issues, but as long as you aren't using the starter Backhoe Loader, you'll be fine without the ability to adjust your seating position to the sides or forward to see better.

Another issue would be that vehicles have basically zero weight. This is most noticeable if you try to drive up on dirt piles or simply... drive a Skid Steer. Your vehicle will be flung around like a rag doll. Under regular operation, you will probably not notice the weightlessness of the vehicles. My problem just stems from habits of actual construction work and things you can do in real life that aren't simulated. But for me, that's fine. It just sadly makes the Skid Steer a useless machine for me.

Those are all the issues I can really gripe on, the rest is just how neat it is to decide what vehicles you want to use for a job outside the recommended machines. You are able to rent machines to complete jobs if need be. The ability to use a single machine for multiple tasks at times is a bonus. This mainly comes down to the excavators being able to lift materials for placements. 

The game is not-sim enough to be forgiving for many of the required tasks like leveling dirt or digging a trench. Even if you don't dig the straightest line or proper depth, once you complete the required area, the next phase will automatically shape it for you as needed. No need to get frustrated over a crooked line. 

The machine types all have very customizable controls. Though it took me a while to set up a few machines to mimic the feel of the machines I'm used to operating in the field, but it's definitely doable.

On another note as an actual construction worker, it is a bit sad that machines like smaller excavators do not allow use of the blade or swing arm. But that is another minor gripe.

Overall, sans experience with multiplayer, I've definitely enjoyed this game for it's simplicity in the tasks despite all it's faults.

This game is like Tonka Construction got a massive overhaul. The game is fun for the most part and enjoyable, Its probably the best construction Sim out right now 10/23/2025. It hits allot of marks you would want in a Construction sim. The negatives are easily overshadowed by the Pro's and enjoyment in it. Plenty of missions to do and can see the region you build change over time. Do i wish there was more? sure but for what the game offers I think its good enough.

Pro's:
* Volumetric soil, gravel, sand, Cement, Asphalt.
* Numerous Types and brands of Construction Equipment
* Three Regions with numerous missions and campaign missions
* Mechanics of the game are easy to learn and play with flexibility of most controls
* Allot of quick options from skipping objectives to fast travel and quick item load ups onto transport
* Dev's watching discussion on Steam support board for game
* V Key to see areas for leveling and seeing what is missed

Cons:
* Track vehicle gameplay mechanics not great but better than it was
* Wish there was even more vehicle types and brands
* No detail on various vehicle's to see what scoops more or holds more.
* Controls for keyboard require you have a keyboard with num pad (not a problem for me).
* Still some bugs in the game but nothing deal breaking plenty of work around's if ran into. Dev's still actively working to improve game so not that big of an issue.

Overall its a great Cons. Sim game and has plenty of room for improvement if not more to look forward to when/if they do a 2nd one. I look forward to see how this game or the future iteration plays out!

This is a fantastic game that doesn't work very well. Don't know what I paid for it, and cost is not the issue. While it worked, it was quite like using the actual equipment. It provides the user with an in game mentor who guides you, and all the projects you could ask for. It's clever, well scripted and not too technical. Unfortunately, about 50 hours into the game, the controllers stopped working for no apparent reason. (They work with my other games.) I tried the support options a couple of times, but they were a waste of time and keystrokes. As best as I can tell, no one provides any kind of support for it. Not Steam, the developers, or anyone on Steam. There's no help, and no fix.  
There isn't even an interface for selecting controllers. None that I could find. No one on Steam seems to have any useful suggestions. Maybe I'm a dummy, but I didn't build an elaborate searchlight with no on/off switch; Or a three-story chalet with no stairs; Or a greenhouse with a tin roof and no windows. This is a technological contradiction, a fabulous game that gradually withdraws features and options that you know it has, until you give up in frustration.

The game looks great. The story is interesting. The NPCs help a lot with the immersion. Driving the wheeled vehicles (except the Bobcat) is a charm. So why the thumb down? A few important (for me) reasons. First, there is a problem with spreading gravel. None of the vehicles, be it the dozer, the loader, the backhoe or the grader, will help you finish that task on contracts. I tried all of them, and although they should handle such a job without problems, none of them does it properly. The grader is actually not bad at it, but for some reasons, it has little to no effect on the percentage of the task. So, even if it does a decent job at spreading the gravel, it won"t help you complete that task. The only vehicles that will allow you to complete those tasks are the dumpers. And good luck for figuring out how to do it. I"ve been playing for 54 hours, and I am still looking for another machine that could do it right.

Second reason: driving the tracked vehicles. Those vehicles are a nightmare to drive, mostly because of the delay in their response to input (in my case, the keyboard/Tartarus keypad). Also because you need two keys to move them forward or backward. I didn`t try the tracked Bobcat for this reason. Instead, I rented the wheeled Bobcat... for about 5 minutes. This vehicle is a joke. Much worse than the tracked vehicles. I could hardly managed to get out of the yard with it. Even though it has wheels, you drive it the same way you would drive a vehicle equipped with tracks (like a tank).

Third reasons: towing the trailer dumper. The physics don`t look right to me. I drove a lot of lories and farm tractors in games, and I backed up a lot of trailers. Farm trailers, which are attached to a standard receiver hitch, are a pain in the butt to back-up. Even farmers have a problem backing them up. Lorie trailers, on the other end, which are attached to a the lorie through a  gooseneck (of fifth-wheel) device, are much easier to back up. It takes some times to get used to it, but when you  get the hang of it, it`s a piece of cake. However, in the game, the dumper trailer, which attaches to the lorie with a simple ball, should be easy to back up, but it ain`t. It behaves more like a farm trailer than a lorie trailer, and is thus a pain in the butt to back up.

I was going to buy the DLC, but han, han, not anymore. Too bad, this game would be a great game without those issues. I remember playing it two years ago. It was crappy then. So this game improved a lot in the last two years. Not enough though. It still has major issues.

It's mostly cranes, cementing, and pushing dirt around. To be fair, it's some of the best dirt manipulation I've ever seen in a video game, but the rest of the game feels empty. There are no consequences to swinging items around too fast on the crane, there is no sandbox option, no hand tools only heavy machinery. The speed of the crane will make you question your life choices. Which kinda sucks because it's all basically cranes and driving. Filling up the dump truck every two feet will also make you go broke very fast (Why does it cost an arm and a leg for some dirt?!)

It's a decent looking game with a day/night cycle, but I kind of wish there was a weather system. Could be interesting to have to deal with unexpected problems like the rain screwing up your cement.

The only real reason I can't recommend this game is that it doesn't really allow the player to be creative in what they build and how. It's not a simulator. It's a crane game with contracts. Even the walls are prefabricated.

Even though it has wheels, you drive it the same way you would drive a vehicle equipped with tracks (like a tank).

Third reasons: towing the trailer dumper. The physics don`t look right to me. I drove a lot of lories and farm tractors in games, and I backed up a lot of trailers. Farm trailers, which are attached to a standard receiver hitch, are a pain in the butt to back-up. Even farmers have a problem backing them up. Lorie trailers, on the other end, which are attached to a the lorie through a  gooseneck (of fifth-wheel) device, are much easier to back up. It takes some times to get used to it, but when you  get the hang of it, it`s a piece of cake. However, in the game, the dumper trailer, which attaches to the lorie with a simple ball, should be easy to back up, but it ain`t. It behaves more like a farm trailer than a lorie trailer, and is thus a pain in the butt to back up.

Farm trailers, which are attached to a standard receiver hitch, are a pain in the butt to back-up. Even farmers have a problem backing them up. Lorie trailers, on the other end, which are attached to a the lorie through a  gooseneck (of fifth-wheel) device, are much easier to back up. It takes some times to get used to it, but when you  get the hang of it, it`s a piece of cake. However, in the game, the dumper trailer, which attaches to the lorie with a simple ball, should be easy to back up, but it ain`t. It behaves more like a farm trailer than a lorie trailer, and is thus a pain in the butt to back up.
